Award.AwardTitle: Characterization and Modeling of New Nanocomposite Materials Termed Covetics

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to study, a new class of nanocomposite materials termed covetics, and compare their behavior to their respective base materials. The nanocomposites consist of a metal matrix and carbon nanofillers which are combined with metal in a new way. The carbon-metal bond is strong and the carbon does not separate out during remelting, laser ablasion or magnetron sputtering. Preliminary results have shown that these materials exhibit some unique structural features and deformation behaviors not seen in traditional metals, and have superior properties to the base metals. However, fundamental knowledge of these materials is lacking. The proposed university-industry collaborative project between the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign and Third Millennium Metals, LLC will address the multi-scale experimental study of the structure and composition, and mechanical, thermal and electrical properties of these materials. These will serve as inputs and validation for multi-scale modeling of these newly discovered materials.

If successful, these studies would lead to a fundamental understanding of these new materials, would stimulate further research on covetics, and facilitate a transition from scientific discovery to commercialization and applications including energy, thermal management, transportation, and environment. The proposed research may potentially lead to new discoveries regarding material structure, bonding, and/or new deformation mechanisms. The knowledge gained would lead to more accurate predictions of properties of nanocomposites, new materials? designs, and more reliable structures, in general. The educational plan focuses on course development and incorporation of findings of this research into existing courses on materials. The results will be published and course notes will be posted on the NSF NanoHub website.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we studied novel nanocarbon materials, called covetics, recently invented by Third Millennium Metals, LLC (Waverly, OH). This is a new class of materials in which the base metal is combined with an activated carbon in a new way, by applying electric current, leading to new materials' behavior.

The objectives of this research projects were to characterize the structure, composition and material properties of aluminum (Al) and copper (Cu) covetics, and to compare them with their respective base metals.

More specifically, we studied the 7075 Al covetics, 6061 Al covetics and 10200 Cu covetics with several different carbon contents (ranging from 0 to 9 weight percent) for each covetic material type and investigated resulting material properties due to the addition of carbon. 

Outcomes

We studied the structure of covetics using scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and e-ray diffraction (XRD). We measured the porosity using micro-computed tomography, and the carbon content using SEM with energy dispersive x-ray spectroscopy (XPS), and measured mechanical properties using tensile and hardness tests, and nanoindentation. We found that the carbon contents were below the ones reported by the manufacturer but still considerably higher than possible carbon contents as predicted by phase diagrams. Also, we used synchrotron at the Argonne National Laboratory to obtain further insights into the covetics materials structure. This provided us with XRD measurements, images of dislocation fields and grains in covetic materials with different carbon contents. We found that in general the addition of carbon reduced the grain size in covetic materials.

In addition, we found improvements in mechanical properties of covetics compared with their respective base metals. More specifically, we found that the increased strength, hardness, and nanoindentation hardness in rolled 7075 Al covetics, and increased hardness, compressive strength and impact energy in as cast 6061 Al and 10200 Cu covetics.

Intellectual Merit

We used state-of-the-art experimental techniques to conduct the multi-scale study of covetic materials. The techniques and experimental methodologies apply to a wider class of materials.

We confirmed the presence of carbon in aluminum and copper covetic, even though phase diagrams show very low solubility of carbon in aluminum and copper. Carbon positively influenced mechanical properties of covetics which make them promising candidates for variety of engineering applications. We confirmed that the added carbon in covetics is integrally bound with the metal. We found that the addition of carbon into a metal in a covetic way leads to simultaneous increases in strength and toughness (ductility). This makes covetics distinct from classical alloys. Deformation modes are also distinct as no necking, traditionally present in metals, was observed. These results show technological promise and merit further fundamental and applied studies.

Broader Impacts

This research should have high impact on the field of materials science and mechanics. We used several state-of-the art techniques for characterizing covetics. Such research provided excellent training opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students who participated in this project. Five graduate students (including two women and one Hispanic male student) and three undergraduate students participated in this research. The developed expertise can be applied to a wide range of metals and alloys. This research was also closely related in scope to the research projects addressed in the NSF I/UCRC on Novel High Voltage/Temperature Materials and Structures (Dr. Jasiuk serves as a site director of this Center). Ten companies (aerospace, power transmission, manufacturing and oil companies) are participating in this Center.

This is a new class of materials in which the base metal is combined with an activated carbon in a new way, by applying electric current, leading to new materials' behavior. The objectives of this research projects were to characterize the structure, composition and material properties of aluminum (Al) and copper (Cu) covetics, and to compare them with their respective base metals.
